title: Energy Deficit
quote:
Remember 1 hour of work = 3 hours of Energy burned
When you make decisions on what gets done today, keep this in mind; you're not lazy. You're running on empty.
appText:
When your tank is empty, it's not about willpower, it's about biology. Energy deficit isn't failure, it's a signal to pause, replenish, and treat rest as essential, not optional.
Youâ€™re not lazy, youâ€™re managing an energy deficit. This card reminds you that rest isnâ€™t weakness â€“ itâ€™s fuel for your healing. Honour your energy, track your output, and adjust your expectations to suit your current reserves.
webContent:
In a healthy person the ratio of work to energy burned is approximately 1:1. In someone who has a health burden it can range up to 4 hours of energy burned for every hour of work conducted. What does that look like? Well taking a middle ground approach lets say the ration is 1:3 for 1 hour of work you burn 3 hours of energy. By the time you finish 1 8 hour day of work, you may have burned 24 hours of energy. Which means in 1 week you will have burned 120 hours worth of energy. Thus creating an Energy deficit. Remember, this is just working hours, it doesnâ€™t include all the hours before work or after work.
What to do? Ask yourself the question, before you start doing an activity or agree to do something for someoneâ€¦ If I choose to do this, how will this impact my energy. This helps 
1 â€“ protect your future energy
2 â€“ build stronger boundaries around your energy needs
3 â€“ learn to say NO when you need to
4 â€“ become more productive and active in your own life.
Remember when people ask you to do something for them its so they can do something they want to do. Often they are asking you to sacrifice your free time, so they can have their free time.
Sometimes itâ€™s not a mindset problemâ€”itâ€™s a metabolic one. Youâ€™re not struggling because you lack willpower. Youâ€™re struggling because your body might be in a state of energy deficit, where basic tasks feel monumental because your system has nothing left in the tank.
This kind of exhaustion may come from many directionsâ€”chronic inflammation, nutrient depletion, nervous system overdrive, poor sleep, or all of the above. Your body is likely prioritising survival functions, and that means everything else takes a hit.
Energy deficit isnâ€™t a sign to push harder. Itâ€™s a signal to pause, recalibrate, and support the body in gentle, consistent ways. You donâ€™t need to earn your restâ€”you need to recognise when itâ€™s non-negotiable.
biomedicalPoints:
1. Mitochondrial dysfunction may impair cellular ATP production, leading to significant fatigue and poor recovery.
Mitochondria are like your bodyâ€™s batteries. When theyâ€™re low, everything feels harder.
2. Chronic stress and inflammation can increase metabolic demand while reducing nutrient absorption.
This may lead to fatigue that doesnâ€™t improve with sleep or food alone.

1. Energy crashes can feel sudden and confusing. You may go from fine to flat with no warning. Try:
Tracking energy dips over a few days
Colour-coding your day by energy levels
Using alarms to check in with your body every 2â€“3 hours
2. Motivation isnâ€™t a reliable gauge. You might feel guilty for not doing more, but itâ€™s not about effort. Try:
Naming your effort: â€œThis is all Iâ€™ve got today, and thatâ€™s okay.â€
Swapping â€œI shouldâ€ for â€œIs this right for me right now?â€
Rewarding any movement, even mental, as progress
3. Your brain might buffer before it crashes. Early warning signs arenâ€™t always obvious. Try:
Using fidget toys or grounding tools to notice overstimulation
Noticing when sentences get harder to form
Checking your postureâ€”slouching might mean your bodyâ€™s flagging

title: The Ta-Dah List
appText:
We often measure our value against how well we complete our to do list. We often overestimate our ability to get things done, we overestimate our capacity to get this all done, so, when the inevitable happens and we donâ€™t get it all done, we see it as a failure, and hereâ€™s the thing, we never get the whole list done. What if we started measuring what we did achieve in a day? I invite you to start a Ta-Daah list. Track and document all the things you managed to do today. This gives us a better and more balanced view of how much we actually do achieve in a day, because realistically, that to do list is never endingâ€¦you will always have things to do
A Ta-Dah List is your permission slip to honour every small victory, no matter how tiny it feels. Instead of focusing on whatâ€™s left, it rewires your brain to register progress. When your energy is precious, noticing effort over output helps rebuild confidence and momentum.
webContent:
We often measure our worth against how many tasks we can tick off a to-do list â€“ but that system is rigged against us from the start. To-do lists are infinite. Life keeps adding more. Our energy fluctuates. Bodies with chronic illness donâ€™t always follow neat productivity schedules. Yet we internalise unfinished lists as personal failure, feeding shame, self-criticism, and that crushing feeling of â€œI should be doing more.â€
The truth is, we consistently underestimate how much we actually do in a day, especially the invisible labour â€“ emotional effort, decision-making, self-regulation, recovery time, pain management, parenting, partner responsibilities, running a home, being a good human. All of this counts. Itâ€™s time we stopped erasing our effort.
Thatâ€™s why we use a Ta-Daah List. Instead of focusing on what didnâ€™t get done, we document what did get done â€“ big or small. It's a daily ritual of acknowledging progress, reclaiming momentum, and restoring self-trust. You are not lazy. You are not failing. You are achieving more than you realise â€“ letâ€™s make it visible.
Start a running Ta-Daah note in your phone or notebook.
Every time you do anything â€“ write it down (eat, rest, hydrate, complete a task, make a call).
At the end of the day, read your list back and say out loud: â€œI did well today.â€
Bonus: Highlight 3 wins â€“ no matter how small â€“ that made today a success.
Use it during rough weeks to rebuild momentum without pressure.
biomedicalPoints:
Chronic illness and neuroinflammation can reduce executive function, lowering motivation and task initiation. Positive reinforcement â€“ like acknowledging accomplishments â€“ stimulates reward pathways that may help improve momentum and emotional regulation.
Research shows that progress tracking can reduce perceived stress and support nervous system regulation by shifting attention from threat (failure) to safety (achievement), activating parasympathetic pathways that support healing.
neurospicyNotes:
Low dopamine = low motivation
Starting is the hardest part. A Ta-Daah list builds dopamine through mini rewards.
âœ… Example: "Sent one email," "Showered," "Replied to one message" â€“ each becomes a micro-win.
Object permanence issues
If you donâ€™t write it down, it feels like it never happened.
âœ… Example: Track emotional wins too â€“ "Didnâ€™t overreact," "Paused before responding," "Rested before crashing."
Rejection Sensitivity / Shame Spirals
A Ta-Daah list breaks the cycle of â€œIâ€™m behindâ€ guilt.
âœ… Example: Include invisible labour â€“ â€œManaged pain flareâ€, â€œSupported a friendâ€, â€œMade a decision I was avoidingâ€.

title: Pattern Interrupt/Reframe
appText:
When you are stuck in your loop, it can be helpful to have a go to interrupter to take you out of your current mindset. When you are trying to create new habits, itâ€™s super easy to talk yourself out of it. Your old tapes run in your head and tell you the things that keep you stuck in your old way of doing things. 
Old patterns run deep â€“ they can keep you stuck on a treadmill youâ€™re no longer interested in running on.  A pattern interrupt is a conscious moment of disruption: stand up, splash water on your face, speak your new truth out loud. It doesnâ€™t need to be fancy. It just needs to break the loop and give your brain a chance to choose something new.
webContent:
When youâ€™re stuck in a behaviour loop, your brain isnâ€™t the enemy â€“ itâ€™s just doing what it has rehearsed. Old patterns are efficient, familiar, and automatic, which means they run even when they no longer serve you. That inner script â€“ those looping thoughts like "Iâ€™ll start tomorrow," "Itâ€™s too hard," "Iâ€™ll never stick to it" â€“ isnâ€™t truth. Itâ€™s conditioning.
Thatâ€™s where a pattern interrupt comes in. Instead of negotiating with yourself for hours and getting stuck in thought spirals, a pattern interrupt cuts through the noise and shifts your state in seconds. It doesnâ€™t fix everything â€“ it simply creates a gap, a moment of choice. In that gap, you can interrupt self-sabotage, emotional spirals, freeze states, procrastination, binge behaviour, stress responses â€“ anything that keeps you stuck in old wiring.
Your job isnâ€™t to fight the loop. Your job is to break it for just long enough to choose differently. One tiny change in momentum can shift your biology, breathing, behaviour and energy â€“ fast. One breath. One phrase. One step. One tiny interrupt that says: â€œWeâ€™re doing it differently now.â€
10 star jumps
Cold water on wrists
Change location (move to a different chair)
Reset breath: In for 4, hold 4, out for 6
"5 things I can see" grounding
â€œ3-2-1 Goâ€ countdown
Put shoes on to activate movement
Play a hype song
2-minute tidy
Open a window for fresh air reset
Step outside barefoot
Set timer + do 5% of a task
Drink water
Say your interrupt phrase: â€œShift.â€
biomedicalPoints:
Pattern interrupts may help calm the amygdalaâ€™s threat response by redirecting neural activity, allowing access to higher executive function and decision-making in the prefrontal cortex.
Interrupting rumination can reduce cortisol and sympathetic arousal, giving the nervous system a chance to shift toward regulation and action.
neurospicyNotes:
ADHD habit loops: Once stuck in freeze or overthinking, task initiation shuts down. Pattern interrupts create a dopamine spark to restart momentum.
âœ… Example: â€œ3-2-1 GOâ€ and stand up.
Autistic overwhelm: Sensory/emotional overload can lock the body. So use gentle, predictable interrupts.
âœ… Example: Weighted object + three deep breaths.
RSD/emotional spirals: Pattern interrupts stop the story before it runs away with you.
âœ… Example: Say out loud: â€œPause. Not facts â€“ just feelings.â€

title: Invisible Progress
quote: Tiny steps lead to big progress
appText:
We often donâ€™t do something small because we donâ€™t see or feel the effect immediately. The progress is too small to measure until we review later down the track. And we donâ€™t see it because small steps often lead to the absence of something such as, not waking up exhausted. 
Healing doesnâ€™t always come with visible milestones. You may not feel â€œbetterâ€ yet â€“ but you might pause before a crash, say no with more ease, or notice your nervous system regulating more often. These are powerful shifts. Invisible progress is still progress. Trust the subtle sign â€“ change is happening, even when itâ€™s quiet.
webContent:
Thereâ€™s a moment, somewhere between exhaustion and acceptance, when you realise youâ€™ve been quietly building something extraordinary without even noticing. We tend to think progress should announce itself â€“ that it should come with fireworks, fanfare, or at least a sense of â€œfinally, this is working.â€ But real healing rarely looks like that. Most of the time, itâ€™s quiet. Itâ€™s subtle. Itâ€™s almost invisible.
We often dismiss the smallest steps because they donâ€™t deliver an immediate shift. We crave evidence â€“ the tangible proof that the effort was worth it. But those small steps are where everything changes. The progress you canâ€™t see is often the most powerful kind, because itâ€™s rewiring your nervous system, recalibrating your hormones, balancing your microbiome, and rebuilding your trust in your body one quiet decision at a time. You might not notice it because it shows up as the absence of struggle â€“ not waking up quite as exhausted, not reacting as strongly, not needing to crash as hard. Itâ€™s the unremarkable moments that mark the start of genuine recovery.
Think about the habits that form the scaffolding of your day. You brush your teeth without thinking about it â€“ a tiny ritual that protects your health over decades. Healing works the same way. Each glass of water you drink, each slow morning stretch, every time you step outside for fresh air, or switch off your phone an hour before bed â€“ these things might seem too small to matter. But they do. Each act tells your body, â€œYou are safe. You are cared for. You can rest now.â€ Over time, those seemingly insignificant habits compound into something powerful: lower inflammation, steadier sleep cycles, calmer hormones, and a nervous system that finally stops scanning for danger.
The body doesnâ€™t transform through grand gestures â€“ it heals through rhythm, through consistency, through those everyday kindnesses repeated again and again. When you reach for nourishment instead of convenience, when you pause to breathe instead of powering through, youâ€™re rewriting the stress chemistry that once ran the show. Invisible progress happens when you keep showing up, even when you canâ€™t feel it working.
One day, youâ€™ll notice that somethingâ€™s shifted. The flare that once took you out for days now fades faster. The noise in your head quiets. The mood swings settle into steadiness. You respond instead of react. It might take months before you see it, but the groundwork is being laid right now, in the small choices you make when no oneâ€™s watching.
So if youâ€™re in a season where everything feels still â€“ where youâ€™re doing the work but canâ€™t see results yet â€“ trust that youâ€™re still moving. The current hasnâ€™t stopped just because you canâ€™t see the ripples. Sometimes the deepest healing happens below the surface, while youâ€™re busy living your ordinary days.
One morning, youâ€™ll look up and realise those tiny, almost invisible actions have carried you across an entire universe. Youâ€™ll see that the progress you once doubted was there all along â€“ tucked quietly into the daily rituals that healed you from the inside out.
Invisible progress isnâ€™t the absence of change â€“ itâ€™s the heartbeat of it. The quiet whisper of your body learning to trust you again. Keep going. Youâ€™re already healing, even when it doesnâ€™t look like it.
biomedicalPoints:
Neuroplasticity thrives on repetition. Small, consistent actions â€“ such as daily stretching, hydration, or deep breathing â€“ reinforce neural pathways that tell the brain â€œThis is safeâ€. Over time, these quiet repetitions rewire stress responses and strengthen parasympathetic regulation.
Circadian rhythm repair begins with routine. Going to bed at the same time, reducing screen exposure in the hour before sleep, and stepping into natural light each morning gradually recalibrates melatonin and cortisol cycles, supporting hormone balance and energy stability.
Micro-movement and micro-nutrition matter. Gentle, regular motion (like morning stretches or short walks) improves lymphatic flow, glucose utilisation, and mitochondrial efficiency. Likewise, hydration and nutrient-dense snacks (nuts, seeds, colourful vegetables) sustain steady blood sugar and reduce inflammatory load.
Healing compounds quietly. The body rebuilds tissue, recalibrates neurotransmitters, and restores gut flora through ongoing small inputs. Just like dental hygiene prevents decay, these daily rituals prevent physiological burnout â€“ even when the results arenâ€™t immediately visible.
neurospicyNotes:
Your brain may crave proof that somethingâ€™s working. Track the small stuff â€“ how many glasses of water, how often you stretched, how long you stayed off screens before bed. Seeing those tiny wins gives your dopamine system something to celebrate.
Use habit stacking: pair a new micro-action (like taking supplements or stretching) with an existing routine (like brushing your teeth or boiling the kettle). It reduces decision fatigue and builds rhythm without pressure.
Create visible cues to anchor invisible progress. Try a bead jar, sticker tracker, or coloured dots on a calendar. Each mark says, â€œI showed up today.â€ Over time, youâ€™ll see the evidence that your effort is real.
Remember: stillness can feel like failure to an ADHD or autistic brain used to urgency. Reframe it â€“ this quietness is integration, not stagnation. Your system is absorbing safety signals at its own pace.

title: Plan For The Crash
appText:
Whether we want to admit it or not. The cyclic nature of autoimmunity. Means that it is likely we are going to crash. Prepping for this. Is the smartest move that you can make. When you are in a crash. It feels like you're insane. And you? Are unable to make good decisions for yourself. At that time. So, while you are well, and things are going the way you want them to, put aside a few things that will help you when you're crashed.
Have a written plan for tough days: safe foods, calming activities, support contacts, and emergency self-care steps. Preparation reduces anxiety and speeds recovery.
webContent:
A crash never feels like progress. It arrives with a heaviness that can make you doubt everything youâ€™ve worked for, and it can stir old fears that youâ€™re back at the beginning again. The emotional and mental load of a crash can be intense, especially if you already manage anxiety, depression, or neurodivergent patterns that affect energy, motivation, or emotional regulation. When your system drops out from under you, climbing back up requires more than strength â€“ it requires strategy, compassion, and preparation.
This is why it helps to have plans tucked away for the days when your capacity disappears without warning. Extra meals in the freezer. A list of what you can let go of immediately. A quiet agreement with family, friends, or colleagues about how they can support you without overwhelming you. A small structure like this doesnâ€™t remove the crash, but it softens the landing. It gives you something to fall into instead of feeling like youâ€™re falling through.
Crashes rarely happen because youâ€™ve failed â€“ they happen because the body has limits. Sometimes we move forward so steadily that we forget how tightly our health relies on rest, pacing, and nervous system balance. Other times, life delivers something sharp: a virus, grief, a job loss, planning a wedding, packing boxes, a house move, the end of a relationship, taking on more than you realised. Even happy events can overload the system. The immune and nervous systems are sensitive storytellers; they react to everything, not just the difficult moments.
What makes a crash more manageable is having a protocol ready long before you need it â€“ a simple list, a rhythm, a sequence that doesnâ€™t require thinking. Something you can hand to a partner, a friend, or even yourself when your brain is foggy, your emotions feel raw, and decision-making becomes impossible. A good protocol can shorten the duration of a crash, prevent the spiral into weeks or months of struggle, and help your body reorient itself sooner. Itâ€™s one of the quietest but most powerful tools you can give yourself on this healing path.

title: Emotional Regulation
appText:
Reframing isn't pretending everything's fine, it's choosing a lens that lightens the load. Shifting your perspective gently can ease stress and make healing feel possible.
Allow yourself to feel big emotions, then gently reframe or redirect. Emotional regulation is a practice - notice, name, and soothe your feelings.
webContent:
Reframing doesnâ€™t mean pretending things are fineâ€”it means choosing how you respond. Your mind has the power to shift your perspective even when your body feels stuck.
If you notice thoughts like â€œIâ€™ll never get better,â€ gently ask, â€œWhat else might be true?â€ This opens up possibility. Maybe healing is slow â€“ but maybe it's still happening. Maybe you didnâ€™t tick every box â€“ but maybe you still moved forward.
Your thoughts arenâ€™t always facts. Catch the ones that feel heavy and flip them just enough to breathe. Reframing isnâ€™t toxic positivity â€“ itâ€™s survival with grace.
biomedicalPoints:
1. Cognitive reframing may reduce limbic system reactivity, which helps with emotional regulation.
â†’ This may lower sympathetic nervous system dominance.
2. Chronic negative thinking patterns may increase pro-inflammatory markers.
â†’ Positive cognitive shifts may reduce the perceived severity of pain and fatigue.
neurospicyNotes:
1. Literal thinking makes reframing hard â€“ but possible.
Use grounded, real-life shifts. Try:
o â€œIâ€™m stuckâ€ â†’ â€œIâ€™m pausing.â€
o â€œI failedâ€ â†’ â€œI learned what didnâ€™t work.â€
o â€œIâ€™m behindâ€ â†’ â€œIâ€™m on my own timeline.â€
2. Reframes stick better with visuals.
Use sensory or visual metaphors. Try:
o â€œThis flare is a fog, not a forever.â€
o Draw a â€œthought ladderâ€ from unhelpful to neutral
o Use colours or stickers to show thought intensity
3. Track reframes like a skill.
Make it a practice, not a pressure. Try:
o Journaling one thought shift per day
o Reframe jars: write negative on one side, positive on the other
o Use voice memos to talk yourself through one better-feeling thought

title: Cha-Cha-Cha
quote: Healing isn't linear. Sometimes it's one step forward, two steps sideways.
appText:

That extra load can increase tension, spike stress hormones, and make the whole thing feel heavier than it already is. When you expect the dance, the hard days stop feeling like personal failure and start looking like part of the choreography.

appText:
Chronic illness brings a very specific kind of grief â€” the grief of losing the life you thought youâ€™d have. Itâ€™s not dramatic, and itâ€™s not self-pity. Itâ€™s the emotional reality of watching your body, energy, identity, and plans shift in ways you never asked for. One day youâ€™re living with all the usual expectations for your age, and the next, youâ€™re dealing with limitations that make you feel decades older than you are.

Because until you acknowledge the losses â€” the routines, abilities, dreams, roles, and freedoms that have changed â€” you canâ€™t decide whatâ€™s possible now, or what needs to be rebuilt.
Grief isnâ€™t giving up. Itâ€™s the bridge between the life you had and the life youâ€™re learning to live. Youâ€™re allowed to honour the past while still choosing hope. Healing requires both.
Allow yourself to process the changes you are going through
webContent:
Chronic illness asks you to confront a truth nobody prepares you for: you will lose things along the way. Not because youâ€™ve failed, but because your body has changed its capacity. And with those changes comes grief â€” not once, but repeatedly. Each time you realise you can no longer do something that used to be effortless, or a plan must be adjusted again, another wave arrives. This is not weakness. This is part of adapting to a new reality.
The grief of chronic illness often arrives earlier than you expect. You may find yourself feeling like an older version of yourself trapped in a younger body. You know what your life should look like, based on age, goals, and social expectations â€” and then your body says, â€œNot today.â€ That conflict between who you were, who you want to be, and what your health allows can be emotionally brutal. You might swing from denial (â€œMaybe Iâ€™ll wake up fine tomorrowâ€) to anger (â€œWhy me?â€), to bargaining (â€œIf I push a little harder maybe I can stillâ€¦â€) to sadness, and at times into acceptance â€” and then the cycle may repeat. This isnâ€™t regression. Itâ€™s adjustment. Every shift in your health invites a new round of recalibration.
The goal of grieving isnâ€™t to erase your past self or abandon the life you wanted. Itâ€™s to make space for an honest understanding of where you are now. Only then can you ask the real questions: Can I adapt this dream? Can I redesign this path? Or is it kinder to myself to let it go and choose something new? These questions arenâ€™t defeat. Theyâ€™re maturity. Theyâ€™re clarity. Theyâ€™re self-protection.
When you allow yourself to grieve, something powerful happens â€” your nervous system stops fighting reality. You stop blaming yourself for being unable to meet old expectations. You stop pushing through emotional pain disguised as determination. Grief lets your body and brain exhale. From there, you can rebuild with intention instead of regret.

Itâ€™s about acknowledging the truth of your experience and choosing a future that works for the you who exists now â€” not the you who existed before illness arrived.

Honour what youâ€™ve lostâ€”but also what youâ€™re building. You are still allowed to hope, plan, and dream. You can hold grief in one hand and growth in the other.
